snippet.textDisplay:
I saw the Opening Ceremony of Beijing olympics. It was good.
But at the middle of the video, there was Hanbok. The Hanbok is Korean's culture, rice cake making and the yut play is also Korean's culture.
Having a grand opening in your own country is a wonderful thing, But you shouldn't use culture of another country in the official Olympics. If you use it, it means that you are stilling another countries culture. Please don't use another contries culture. Use your own countries culture.
snippet.textOriginal:
I saw the Opening Ceremony of Beijing olympics. It was good. 
But at the middle of the video, there was Hanbok. The Hanbok is Korean's culture, rice cake making and the yut play is also Korean's culture.
Having a grand opening in your own country is a wonderful thing, But you shouldn't use culture of another country in the official Olympics. If you use it, it means that you are stilling another countries culture. Please don't use another contries culture. Use your own countries culture.

snippet.textDisplay:
@wang qi e year after destroying Gojoseon, in 107 BC, Emperor Wu of the Western Han Dynasty, established Hyeondo (Xuantu) Commandery (First Hyeondo Commandery) with Okjeo Fortress as its ruling place, and put Okjeo and Yemaek under its jurisdiction. Shortly before 75 BC, when the Wuhuan of Liaodong revolted, the Western Han drafted delinquent youths and criminal officials from the metropolitan and provincial areas into the army and stationed them in Liaodong. It also relocated Hyeondo Commandery to Liadong (Second Hyeondo Commandery), with the construction of Hyeondo Fortress there to prepare against the invasion of the Wuhuan. As the Second Hyeondo Commandery was located in the area where the Guryeo, the indigenous tribe, resided, the area was named Guryeo County after this tribe and made the ruling place of the commandery. Guryeo was initially treated as a “hu,” which was equivalent to a county, by the Western Han, but as the Wuhuan surrendered during the reign of Emperor Huan, it was promoted to a “wang” (principality) that corresponded to a commandery in recognition of its contribution to the victory in 37 BC (second year of Jianzhao) during the reign of Emperor Yuan who succeeded Emperor Huan. This may be the reason why it is recorded in Samguk Sagi (History of the Three Kingdoms) that Goguryeo was founded in 37 BC. Around this time, the Guryeo was given “Go as their surname from the Western Han and changed their country’s name from Guryeo to Goguryeo, with musicians and performers granted by the emperor in celebration or its elevated status. At this time, the name of Guryeo County in Hyeondo Commandery was also changed to Goguryeo County, which appears in the “Treatise on Geography of the Book of Han that describes the situation of the late Western Han. Then, when Wang Mang, the founder of the Xin Dynasty, tried to subjugate the Xiongnu by mobilizing the people of Goguryeo, it rose up against the policy around 12 AD and became independent outside the boundaries of the Second Hyeondo Commandery. The Later Han Dynasty that succeeded the Xin Dynasty, recognized the title of wang” to maintain relations with the independent Goguryeo, and built a small fortress called Chaekguro Fortress on the eastern border of the Second Hyeondo Commandery where it bestowed o&cial uniforms, clothes and headwears on the people of Goguryeo at special occasions.
This is an academic paper material

snippet.textDisplay:
@wang qi In general, it is thought that Yein, which spread in the forest area of ​​the eastern part of the Korean Peninsula from the Songhwa River basin to the east of the upper Yoha, developed into Buyeo and Okjeo, and Macin in the west developed into Goguryeo. 'Mac' is one of the common names of northern powers that appeared several centuries before the founding of Goguryeo, and gradually became fixed as a term referring to Goguryeo. is not yet visible However, looking at the contents of the tombstone of King Gwanggaeto's tombstone, it can be assumed that the inhabitants of the village refer to the people of Goguryeo, in other words, from the contents that they were forced to live together with the residents because they were afraid that they might not know the etiquette.

It seems that a population group represented by stone tombs (Jokseokchong) has been formed in the Jib-Hwanin area from around the 3rd century BC, and it is said that it was invaded by Lee Maek when the 1st Hyeondo army was ousted later, where Lee Maek was the Guryeo people, that is, the original Guryeo. It is the prevailing opinion since Jehogyu that a group was established and a political system worthy of being called Goguryeo was established around this time around 75 BC. However, there is no common sense that Goguryeo has been a centralized country since then. In fact, based on the record that there were several people who received drums and trumpets [3] in Hyeondo-gun before the East of the Three Kingdoms period, it is an alliance that unites with each other in major events, but usually plays separately. Since Roh Tae-don, the prevailing theory has been that the leading force was Songyang's Biryubu, but was defeated by Jumong and replaced with Gyerubu.

In addition, the volleyball game of Suseo explains that the country called Gojukguk is the origin of Goguryeo. Goguryeo ruled the Daereung River Basin, but before Goguryeo, the Goguryeo Kingdom, which existed in the Daereung River Basin, was brought into the territory of Goguryeo. He created the logic of conquering the realm.

In the case of Goguryeo-hyeon appearing in “Hanseo” Geography, in the “Samguksagi” Goguryeo Bongi, Yuri Wangdae, there is a record that Cucumber and Mari were ordered to occupy Yangmaek and Goguryeo-hyeon belonging to Hyeondo-gun. link. This is a factor that confuses those who read the first Samguk Sagi and Goguryeo Bongi. This point can be interpreted as there was a large administrative district centered on the 'Goguryeo-hyeon' area where the prefectural governor's office was installed. have. To put it simply, Seoul City Hall was established for administration in Jung-gu in the area called 'Seoul', and the 'Seoul Kingdom' appeared in Gwanak-gu and occupied Seoul City Hall as a record.[4]

According to a commonly known myth, Jumong (= King Chumo), a native of Bukbuyeo, founded Jolbon in 37 BC. However, his story of founding is very similar to that of King Dongmyeong of Buyeo. The myth of the founding of Buyeo is the first to appear in the 《Neonhyeong》 written by Wangchung in the early years of the East Han Dynasty, and this form of the founding myth appears in the Buyeojo dynasty even before the Weseo dynasty in the 3rd century 『The Three Kingdoms』, while there is no related content in the Goguryeo dynasty. However, in the early 5th century, the myth of the founding of Goguryeo was confirmed in documents such as 『Moduru Tomb Name』 and 『Gwanggaeto the Great Queen』. Seongwang', and this was published in the Samguk Sagi. If the myth of Goguryeo was borrowed from Goguryeo as a general interpretation, it means that the myth of the founding of Goguryeo completely devoured the myth of the founding of Buyeo.

Seongwang', and this was published in the Samguk Sagi. snippet.textDisplay:
@wang qi According to legend, Jumong and his party, who traveled south from Buyeo, settled in Jolbon, upstream of the Yalu River, south of Buyeo, and founded Goguryeo in BC. Although it has a strong image represented by the Manchurian Plains, it is believed that it developed into a predatory economy because of its lack of productivity due to its location in the rugged mountainous terrain near Jolbonseong and Dokseonseong at the beginning of the country's founding. At the time of the founding of the country, the military and county of Han and Wei were holding on to the west and south, so it did not expand significantly in the two directions to the southwest and could only be occupied later. Predatory or progressive oppression strategies were predominant. Instead, it extended to the southeast from early on and subjugated various powers in the Tuman River area such as Okjeo and Dongye, as well as in Hamgyeong-do and Gangwon-do. In addition to these orthodoxy, there is also an argument that the location and conquest of Goguryeo in the early period should be moved further east than the current speculation.

At the beginning of the 4th century, King Micheon took the lead in the chaos of China's West Jin, represented by the Rebellion of the Eight Kings, wiped out the Nakrang and Daebang forces, and completely took control of the present northern part of the Korean Peninsula, unifying all groups that previously belonged to Wiman Joseon. However, after unsuccessful efforts to block the Moyongbu scholars who emerged in the Ryoho region with other scholars such as Dan and Umun, they were allowed to exchange foreign currency within the country for a while. At this time, Buyeo, which was closer to Moyongbu, practically collapsed. After the Northern Wei put pressure on the Northern Yan and waged a war with Northern Yan, the Goguryeo Dynasty became the ruler of Northern Yan, and they made peace. Even in the south, Baekje was at its peak, and King Gogukwon was killed, and he was put on the defensive.

At the beginning of the 5th century, taking advantage of the strength of the alms-bearing scholars, they expelled the Moyongbu scholars from Yodong. In the south, they defeated Baekje and took Wiryeseong Fortress, and expanded their power to the Jungwon area of ​​Chungcheong Province, driving the combined forces of Baekje, Wa, and Gaya that invaded Silla. By saving my life, I am in my prime by interfering in internal affairs and receiving tribute. After that, Baekje and Silla barely maintained the status quo as the Naje alliance, and they occupied most of the Buyeo area, exclusively in Yodong, for about two hundred years before Sui and the Tang intervened.

In the later period, it expanded its territory to the south and moved to Pyongyang Fortress, transforming it into a country centered on the northern part of the Korean Peninsula. This contact point with the southern part of the Korean Peninsula, along with the reunification of the northern part of the Korean peninsula, which had been dispersed since the fall of Wiman Joseon, is the basis for the inclusion of Goguryeo in Korean history and the establishment of a country called Goryeo. As Silla reached its heyday, its territory was relatively reduced compared to its heyday, but nevertheless, it did not lose its status as the largest country among the three kingdoms.

Stimulated by the growth of Goguryeo, the waterway gathered strength to check Goguryeo, but in the middle of the 6th century, it was rather divided into 7 Malgal divisions by Goguryeo, which became the foundation for the founding of Goguryeo's successor state, Balhae. In addition, Goguryeo controlled the Khitan tribes in the Yoseo area and the Malgal tribes in Manchuria before and after its heyday, and the popularity of Goguryeo increased by fighting a war that risked its existence against the invasion of the Chinese dynasty. come.

namukiki doesn't lie neither^^
snippet.textOriginal:
@wang qi According to legend, Jumong and his party, who traveled south from Buyeo, settled in Jolbon, upstream of the Yalu River, south of Buyeo, and founded Goguryeo in BC. Although it has a strong image represented by the Manchurian Plains, it is believed that it developed into a predatory economy because of its lack of productivity due to its location in the rugged mountainous terrain near Jolbonseong and Dokseonseong at the beginning of the country's founding. At the time of the founding of the country, the military and county of Han and Wei were holding on to the west and south, so it did not expand significantly in the two directions to the southwest and could only be occupied later. Predatory or progressive oppression strategies were predominant. Instead, it extended to the southeast from early on and subjugated various powers in the Tuman River area such as Okjeo and Dongye, as well as in Hamgyeong-do and Gangwon-do. In addition to these orthodoxy, there is also an argument that the location and conquest of Goguryeo in the early period should be moved further east than the current speculation.

At the beginning of the 4th century, King Micheon took the lead in the chaos of China's West Jin, represented by the Rebellion of the Eight Kings, wiped out the Nakrang and Daebang forces, and completely took control of the present northern part of the Korean Peninsula, unifying all groups that previously belonged to Wiman Joseon. However, after unsuccessful efforts to block the Moyongbu scholars who emerged in the Ryoho region with other scholars such as Dan and Umun, they were allowed to exchange foreign currency within the country for a while. At this time, Buyeo, which was closer to Moyongbu, practically collapsed. Even in the south, Baekje was at its peak, and King Gogukwon was killed, and he was put on the defensive.

At the beginning of the 5th century, taking advantage of the strength of the alms-bearing scholars, they expelled the Moyongbu scholars from Yodong. In the south, they defeated Baekje and took Wiryeseong Fortress, and expanded their power to the Jungwon area of ​​Chungcheong Province, driving the combined forces of Baekje, Wa, and Gaya that invaded Silla. By saving my life, I am in my prime by interfering in internal affairs and receiving tribute. After that, Baekje and Silla barely maintained the status quo as the Naje alliance, and they occupied most of the Buyeo area, exclusively in Yodong, for about two hundred years before Sui and the Tang intervened.

In the later period, it expanded its territory to the south and moved to Pyongyang Fortress, transforming it into a country centered on the northern part of the Korean Peninsula. This contact point with the southern part of the Korean Peninsula, along with the reunification of the northern part of the Korean peninsula, which had been dispersed since the fall of Wiman Joseon, is the basis for the inclusion of Goguryeo in Korean history and the establishment of a country called Goryeo. As Silla reached its heyday, its territory was relatively reduced compared to its heyday, but nevertheless, it did not lose its status as the largest country among the three kingdoms.

Stimulated by the growth of Goguryeo, the waterway gathered strength to check Goguryeo, but in the middle of the 6th century, it was rather divided into 7 Malgal divisions by Goguryeo, which became the foundation for the founding of Goguryeo's successor state, Balhae. In addition, Goguryeo controlled the Khitan tribes in the Yoseo area and the Malgal tribes in Manchuria before and after its heyday, and the popularity of Goguryeo increased by fighting a war that risked its existence against the invasion of the Chinese dynasty. come.

snippet.textDisplay: @wang qi If you use a translator, it may be translated strangely, but in Chinese records, many countries, such as Buyeo and Goguryeo, say dong. And, of course, genetically similar. Sadly, our country has been subjected to many invasions. Then a lot of blood is mixed. But that doesn't make us Chinese. And before the Cultural Revolution, China had a lot of great culture. It is a pity that China destroys its own culture with its own hands and now claims the culture of other countries as its own.
